Response: Santa Rosa's high priority Care Redesign Intervention was around shared decision-making, specifically pertaining to the pre-operative and 90 day post-acute time frame.  In addition to the current Total Joint Patient Navigator, a new role entitled the "Bundled Payment Care Manager" was created.  The focus of the Bundled Payment Care Manager is to guide and coordinate high and rising risk patients through multiple care delivery systems, with emphasis on training the providers and downstream episode participants (SNF, Home Care, OP Physical Therapy) on implementation of patient risk screening/risk mitigation tools, in addition to engaging patient's family/caregiver/coach in the decision making process.

Success around our Care Redesign Interventions are evident in the increased communication across the entire care continuum.  Whether it's a phone call from an Outpatient Physical Therapist with a concern around a total knee patient's range of motion, or a Saturday evening call from a SNF requesting assist to help avoid a patient readmission, our increased communication is audible!  Challenges/barriers arise with our extensive geographic reach and rural settings which make it even more evident that our strategy around the Bundled Payment Care Manager role being necessary for the pre-operative optimization of the patient and the success of the overall program in terms of outcomes, readmission reduction and patient satisfaction.
NA; we are a Non-Convener Participant

Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital has established agreements with qualified skilled nursing facilities in the primary service area, as mandated by CMS for the use of the 3-Day SNF Waiver, of which is working well.  Our challenges lie in the fact that our patient geographic reach spans hundreds of miles wide, thus our skilled nursing providers in the secondary service area are not as easily in communication/collaboration with the needs of BPCI-Advanced.  Further, would appreciate more specific language around "Participating Practitioners", to supply a more specific response.

We have tools and records in place to support such an event. All BPCI participants are tracked manually (excel spreadsheet) and confirmed with CMS claims data as received.  Ongoing education provided for BPCI-A care continuum, including physicians, case management, nursing/rehab and community care providers (SNF, Home Health, Rehab).  Ongoing data tracker created (Bundled Payment Performance Dashboard) was created by our health system and supports day-to-day performance and decision making.
The only caveat would be supplying a Spanish version, if needed.
NA; we have not yet implemented a system for monitoring and responding to beneficiary complaints
NA; no complaint monitoring system yet

Challenges would include short turn around times for large healthcare systems; complicated forms and data requests; too frequent of requests. Also, a continuous challenge is the overlap of all CMS models, and unclear compliance requirements.

Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital is participating in BPCI-A for Lower Extremity Joint Replacement and Upper Extremity Joint Replacement.  The main challenges that we have found with the Lower Extremity Joint Replacement cohort is that hip fracture/hemiarthroplasty patients are included in this group.  Although risk adjusted, the majority of this patient population is high acuity and requires great resources (lengthy hospital LOS, extended SNF stays, multiple comorbidities, higher incidence of readmission) and as a result, this non-elective population is straining the target bundle price. Our recommendation or ask would be that for this Clinical Episode, as with all BPCI-A Clinical Episodes, CMS apply a target price per DRG, and possibly even broken out by (in this case) w/ and w/o fractures. This would account for the patient acuity, and be more appropriate.
